meanings.def: measuring a long distance from the bottom to the top
examples: What's the highest mountain in the US?
The house has a high wall all the way round it.
shoes with high heels
He has a round face with a high forehead.

meanings.def: used to talk about the distance that something measures from the bottom to the top
examples: How high is Everest?
It's only a low wall—about a metre high.
The grass was waist-high.
knee-high boots

meanings.def: at a level that is a long way above the ground or above the level of the sea
examples: a high branch/shelf/window
The rooms had high ceilings.
streaks of high cloud
They were flying at high altitude.
the grasslands of the high prairies
The fence is over five metres high.
He has climbed some of the world’s highest mountains.
How high was the plane when the engine failed?
My brother’s much taller than me.
She ordered cold beer in a tall glass.
tall factory chimneys
Tall pine trees line the roadways.
The only windows in the hall were narrow and high.
There was a light quite high up.

meanings.def: greater or better than normal in quantity or quality, size or degree
examples: a high price/cost/speed/temperature
a high rate of inflation
high levels of pollution
Demand is high at this time of year.
high-quality goods
a high risk of injury
a high standard of craftsmanship
A high proportion of our staff are female.
Originally, an even higher percentage of land was wetlands.
A high degree of accuracy is needed.
The cost in terms of human life was high.
higher than… Sales were significantly higher than in previous years.
The tree blew over in the high winds.
We had high hopes for the business (= we believed it would be successful).
Asparagus grows faster at higher temperatures.
Can we hire a car here?
Look! There are rowing boats for hire on the lake!
There is an extremely high drop-out rate.
Unemployment remained high for several years.
Vets have a relatively high suicide rate.
High council taxes have forced several local businesses to relocate.
They charge very high prices for a pretty average service.
Acids, by definition, have a higher concentration of hydrogen ions than plain water.
It is critical for the company to maintain a high profile.

meanings.def: containing a lot of a particular substance
examples: a high potassium content
a high-fat diet
high in something foods that are high in fat
Oranges are high in vitamin C.

meanings.def: near the top in rank, status or importance
examples: She has held high office under three prime ministers.
The case was referred to a higher court.
the distinction between high art and popular art
high on something Job security is high on his list of priorities.

meanings.def: of great value
examples: to play for high stakes
My highest card is ten.
high against something At the moment, the euro is high against the dollar, which makes for a good exchange rate.
The high dollar is still a major problem for importers.

meanings.def: when a river or the tide is high, the water reaches a long way up the river bank, beach, etc.
examples: The river was very high and threatening to flood.

meanings.def: morally good
examples: a man of high ideals/principles

meanings.def: showing a lot of approval or respect for somebody
examples: She is held in very high regard by her colleagues.
You seem to have a high opinion of yourself!

meanings.def: at the upper end of the range of sounds that humans can hear; not deep or low
examples: She has a high voice.
That note is definitely too high for me.
Your voice sounds very high on the telephone.
a fairly high pitch

meanings.def: used to describe the middle or the most attractive part of a period of time
examples: high noon
high summer

meanings.def: beginning to go bad and having a strong smell
behaving in an excited way because of the effects of alcohol or drugs
examples: He was high on drugs.

meanings.def: produced with the mouth in a relatively closed position
to behave in a way that shows you think you are better than other people
friends, people, etc. in positions of power and influence
examples: He has friends in high places.

meanings.def: to enjoy yourself very much
despite any difficulties
examples: I was determined to go, come hell or high water.

meanings.def: in a position out of the water
examples: Their yacht was left high and dry on a sandbank.

meanings.def: in a difficult situation, without help or money
behaving as though you think you are more important than other people
behaving in a very excited way, especially because of being strongly affected by alcohol or drugs
the amount of attention somebody/something has from the public
examples: This issue has had a high profile in recent months.
I advised her to keep a low profile for the next few days (= not to attract attention).
The story was given a low profile in today's papers.

meanings.def: in an angry or offended mood, and showing other people that you are angry
examples: He stomped out of the room in high dudgeon.
She stormed out in high dudgeon.

meanings.def: used to say that you think somebody should do something soon
examples: It's about time you cleaned your room!

meanings.def: of a high quality or degree; of the highest quality or greatest degree
examples: The job requires diplomatic skills of a high order.
She was a snob of the first order.

meanings.def: to have a strong unpleasant smell
to seem to be very dishonest or morally unacceptable
to claim that your side of an argument is morally better than your opponents’ side; to argue in a way that makes your side seem morally better
examples: I was angry with his blatant attempt to take the moral high ground.

idioms.def: to behave in a way that shows you think you are better than other people

idioms.idiom: friends, people, etc. in high places
idioms.def: friends, people, etc. in positions of power and influence
examples: He has friends in high places.
I was determined to go, come hell or high water.

idioms.def: in a position out of the water
examples: Their yacht was left high and dry on a sandbank.

idioms.def: behaving as though you think you are more important than other people
behaving in a very excited way, especially because of being strongly affected by alcohol or drugs
the amount of attention somebody/something has from the public
examples: This issue has had a high profile in recent months.
I advised her to keep a low profile for the next few days (= not to attract attention).
The story was given a low profile in today's papers.

idioms.def: in an angry or offended mood, and showing other people that you are angry
examples: He stomped out of the room in high dudgeon.
She stormed out in high dudgeon.

idioms.def: used to say that you think somebody should do something soon
examples: It's about time you cleaned your room!

idioms.idiom: of a high order | of the highest/first order
idioms.def: of a high quality or degree; of the highest quality or greatest degree
examples: The job requires diplomatic skills of a high order.
She was a snob of the first order.

idioms.idiom: smell, stink, etc. to high heaven
idioms.def: to have a strong unpleasant smell

idioms.idiom: take, claim, seize, etc. the moral high ground
idioms.def: to claim that your side of an argument is morally better than your opponents’ side; to argue in a way that makes your side seem morally better
examples: I was angry with his blatant attempt to take the moral high ground.

meanings.def: at or to a position or level that is a long way up from the ground or from the bottom
examples: to climb/jump/leap high
I can't jump any higher.
An eagle soared high overhead.
His desk was piled high with papers.
high above (something) The castle sits high above the wooded valley.
A plane flew high above.

meanings.def: at or to a large value, amount or price
examples: Prices are expected to rise even higher this year.
Students who scored high on the test went on to do very well.
They buy shares low and sell them high.

meanings.def: to or at an important position
examples: She never rose very high in the company.
She's aiming high (= hoping to be very successful) in her exams.

meanings.def: at a high pitch
examples: I can't sing that high.

meanings.def: to be successful or very confident
examples: The company is riding high this year.

meanings.def: to be successful
examples: British cinema has been flying high recently, winning several coveted awards.

meanings.def: everywhere
examples: I've searched high and low for my purse.

meanings.def: to be proud of or not feel ashamed about something that you have done
examples: She managed to hold her head high and ignore what people were saying.

meanings.def: to be strong and angry or excited
examples: Feelings ran high as the election approached.

idioms.def: to be successful or very confident
examples: The company is riding high this year.
British cinema has been flying high recently, winning several coveted awards.
I've searched high and low for my purse.

idioms.idiom: hold your head high | hold up your head
idioms.def: to be proud of or not feel ashamed about something that you have done
examples: She managed to hold her head high and ignore what people were saying.

idioms.def: to be strong and angry or excited
examples: Feelings ran high as the election approached.

meanings.def: the highest level or number
examples: to hit/reach a high
Exports are currently at record highs.
Profits reached an all-time high last year.
Share prices reached an all-time high yesterday.
The number of prisoners has reached a historic high.
Oil prices hit a high of $70 a barrel yesterday.

meanings.def: an area of high air pressure; an anticyclone
examples: A high over southern Europe is bringing fine, sunny weather to all parts.

meanings.def: the highest temperature reached during a particular day, week, etc.
examples: Highs today will be in the region of 25°C.

meanings.def: the feeling of extreme pleasure and excitement that somebody gets after taking some types of drugs
examples: The high lasted all night.
The drug gives you a tremendous high.
the high she got from cocaine

meanings.def: the feeling of extreme pleasure and excitement that somebody gets from doing something fun or being successful at something
examples: He was on a real high after winning the competition.
the highs and lows of her acting career
the emotional highs and lows of an actor's life
This show is our swansong—we want to finish on a high.
He was still on a natural high after cheating death.
She's been on a real high since she got her exam results.
He hit a career high with his performance as Al.

meanings.def: used in the name of a high school
examples: He graduated from Little Rock High in 2012.

meanings.def: in a high place
examples: We gazed down into the valley from on high.

meanings.def: the people in senior positions in an organization
examples: An order came down from on high that lunchbreaks were to be half an hour and no longer.

meanings.def: in heaven
examples: The disaster was seen as a judgement from on high.
We gazed down into the valley from on high.
An order came down from on high that lunchbreaks were to be half an hour and no longer.
The disaster was seen as a judgement from on high.
